title.rendered: Residence Vive La Vie: A Scenic Sojourn in Franschhoek

content.rendered:
Situated on Uitkyk Street, just a short stroll from the village buzz, this scenic guesthouse is the perfect spot to relax and recharge after a day spent exploring. The expansive garden and soothing interiors imbue the property with a sense of tranquility that wash over you the moment you step through the doors.

Home attraction


A sense of home comfort flows throughout the property, from the way in which the five suites are decorated to the spacious outdoor patio, which offers guests a comfortable space to relax, enjoy a braai, and listen to chilled beats while soaking up the scene.


The beautiful garden simply glows in the sunlight, and surrounds a large lap pool decked with sun loungers for lazy afternoon naps under the shaded canopy.


The guesthouse serves breakfast in the bright open-plan dining area alongside the large kitchen. In addition to your very own tier of freshly baked pastries, fruit, and cold meats and cheeses set at your table, a menu featuring hot breakfasts is also available.

La suite life

The double-storey house has five rooms: three in the main house (Superior King Suite 1 and 2, and Superior Double Suite 3), and two (Standard Double Room 4 and Superior King Suite 5) situated in a garden cottage.

Superior King Suite 1

  • Full en-suite bathroom
  • Small lounge area
  • Private outdoor patio
  • King-size bed
  • Complimentary sparkling wine on arrival
  • Mini fridge
  • Nespresso machine and complimentary coffee pods
  • Tea-making station
  • TV with select DStv channels
  • Rain Africa toiletries
  • European charging ports
  • Hair dryer
  • Air conditioning

Vive La Vie – French for “Living Life” – hints at the sense of rejuvenation you’ll feel at the end of a stay in this serene setting. With a passionate team of staff available round the clock, guests are encouraged to relax, recharge and revel at the Residence.

title.rendered: The Last Word: Beautiful Boutique Accommodation in Franschhoek

content.rendered:
This wonderfully intimate boutique hotel is one of three in The Last Word group of hotels, which features properties in Kommetjie and Constantia, too. Its prime position – just off Franschhoek’s bustling main road – belies what lies beyond the towering wrought-iron gates… an oasis of tranquility.


Built around a 200-year-old oak tree (checked upon monthly by the resident “tree doctor”), the hotel’s Cape Dutch exterior blends seamlessly with the architecture in the village, with each one of the spacious suites exuding luxe comfort.

Lovely lodgings



An intimate number of just 10 suites ensures that the tranquil ambience of the property remains undisturbed – each elegantly decorated in soft hues of blue, lilac and cream.

Superior Double Suites
There are eight super double suites spread across the lower and upper level of the hotel, each with a private patio, soft-carpeted floors, a large double bed (decked with 30-thread-count cotton linen), a spacious bathroom with a bath and shower, and a mini bar with complimentary drinks and snacks.

Room features:

  • Complimentary mini bar snacks
  • Fresh flowers
  • Carafe of port or sherry
  • Underfloor heating
  • Free Wi-fi
  • Heated towel rails
  • Tea and coffee station
  • Bluetooth radio
  • Flatscreen TV with select DStv channels
  • DVD player
  • Telephone
  • Air conditioning
  • Hair dryer and shaving points
  • Room safe

Cost From R2 250 per suite per night (depending on season)

Pool Suites
The two luxurious pool suites line the sparkling pool, and boast their own private lounges, courtyards, deck chairs and direct access to a personal plunge pool. There is also a semi-heated pool available to all guests.

Room features:

  • Complimentary mini bar snacks
  • Fresh flowers
  • Carafe of port or sherry
  • Underfloor heating
  • Free Wi-fi
  • Heated towel rails
  • Tea and coffee station
  • Bluetooth radio
  • Flatscreen TV with select DStv channels
  • DVD player
  • Telephone
  • Air conditioning
  • Hair dryer and shaving points
  • Room safe

Cost From R7 200 per suite per night (depending on season)

At your service


In addition to the sumptuous rooms, the hotel offers a daily complimentary breakfast set out each morning in the sun-kissed dining area, while the cosy lounge is the perfect spot to relax with glass of port, and play a boardgame, before heading out on the town in the evening.

A fully stocked bar filled with usual favourites is available for those seeking a happy-hour tipple or a relaxing night cap. And, on the upstairs balcony is a relaxation area with cushioned loungers that boasts breathtaking views of the mountain, and village below.

Those wanting to get out and explore the surrounding farms can arrange to do so with the in-house chauffeur (which costs extra). Or, if you’re feeling energetic, hop on one of the hotel’s bicycles.

If you’re more of a pamper-and-relax kind of person, then an indulgent spa treatment can be arranged for you to enjoy in the comfort of your suite.

Whether you’re in town for a night, or you’re looking to spend a few days in this winelands oasis, The Last Word should be a whisper on your lips.

title.rendered: Lily Pond House: Luxurious Villa Living at Le Lude in Franschhoek

content.rendered:
Franschhoek is home to an abundance of wine farms scattered across the rolling hills of its picturesque valley. Once such place is Le Lude, home to a world-renowned range of Cap Classique and the famed Orangerie Restaurant – which is, surprisingly, not where the magic ends.

Situated on the edge of the estate, overlooking a tranquil, duck-dotted river, Lily Pond House is the farm’s villa, and the ultimate hidden hideaway. A short drive from the estate’s main building along the cyprus-lined dirt road, the secluded home is a masterpiece in itself, boasting spellbinding vineyard views.


Mark Le Grange

Mark Le Grange

Simple white walls and elegant pillars set the scene outside, while high ceilings, elegant decor and shuttered windows create an interior that’s wonderfully reminiscent of a classic farm manor house.

Countryside comfort




Afristay

If you’re seeking luxurious seclusion, this spot is calling your name. From the moment you arrive, everything is ready for you, right down to the keys waiting in the door. In fact, the only time you’ll see any of the estate’s staff is when they come to clean once a day (however, they are always available should you need them).

The home is completely self-catering, and has a large, fully equipped open-plan kitchen stocked with utensils and pantry cupboard staples – and even a chilled bottle of Le Lude MCC waiting in the fridge.

The spacious open-plan living area, complete with wi-fi, TV, a desk and couches, leads onto the verandah, perfect for alfresco soirées.

The two identical bedrooms, on opposite ends of the house, are divided by large wooden doors. Each boasts a large double bed (which can be made into a twin), underfloor heating throughout, air-conditioning, a TV, and an en-suite bathroom, with a shower and a freestanding Victorian bath. (We recommend opening the shutters as you take a soak, so you can gaze at the breathtaking vineyard views beyond.)

On your doorstep



Never Ending Voyage

Overlooking the river, the garden is a wonderfully tranquil place to kick up your feet and relax. In addition to a lovely plunge pool lined by sun loungers, there’s an outdoor dining area accompanied by a braai and firewood for lazy afternoon lunches in the sun, or dinner beneath the stars.

You’ll even have access to your own private bridge across the river, leading to a short walk among the flowers and lily pond. Not mention the MCC tasting room and Orangerie Restaurant, only a short saunter away!

This private villa is the perfect place for a relaxing countryside getaway. A few nights here, and you’ll never want to leave.

title.rendered: Macaron Boutique Guest House: Smalltown Seclusion in Franschhoek

content.rendered:
Situated on the corner of a quaint residential road, a stone’s throw away from Franschhoek’s buzzy centre, Macaron Boutique Guest House offers countryside comfort while still remaining close to the town’s sought-after scene.

Housed in a beautiful Victorian home, the intimate guesthouse offers nine rooms spread over two buildings. And, despite its central location, the property features a large garden, with two pools, imbuing an undeniable sense of tranquility, making it a wonderful Franschhoek escape.

Named after the most delicate of French pastries (and the most difficult to perfect), the guesthouse prides itself on the utmost attention to detail, from the dreamy decor in each room, to the attentive staff and special service. Let’s just say this is one stay you’re going to love tucking into!

Suite like sugar

The nine rooms range in size and features, but all are utterly comfortable and dressed in earthy, natural tones. In each one, you’ll find a selection of local cookbooks and up-to-date editions of your favourite magazines, as well as two delectable macarons, naturellement.

The larger suites boast a desk and sitting area, with some housing a fireplace.

Room features:

  • Ensuite bathroom with shower
  • Private entrance
  • Complimentary tea and coffee
  • Free Wi-fi
  • TV with select DStv channels
  • Room safe
  • Bathrobe and slippers
  • Umbrellas
  • Mini fridge (costs extra)
  • Charlotte Rhys toiletries

Above and beyond

During winter, a fire roars in the cosy lounge, where blankets and a selection of board games are on display for your choosing. On warmer days, lounge by the private lap pool on a deck chair, or cool off with a quick dip.

A full continental breakfast is served each morning in the lounge or on the terrace. In addition to a lovely selection of cereal, yoghurt, fresh seasonal fruit and array of cheese, bread, cold meats and juices, guests can order a hot breakfast of your choice.

In the evening, take a stroll to one of the world-class neighbouring restaurants, before returning to the comfort of your room to find the curtains drawn, your bed turned down, and the following day’s weather (complete with a chocolate and a cosy hot water bottle in winter) resting on your pillow.

It’s the sense of escapism and undeniable comfort combined with the proximity to Franschhoek’s high street that made my stay at Macaron so enjoyable.

title.rendered: Kagga Kamma: A Comfortable Cave Getaway in the Cederberg

content.rendered:
An almost four-hour drive from noisy Cape Town lies Kagga Kamma Nature Reserve, a slice of untouched wilderness in the heart of the Cederberg with a unique accommodation offering. Enhanced by breathtaking views of the stark landscape by day and the starlit sky at night, it’s the sort of place where unforgettable memories are made.

Cave in

Accommodation comes in the form of 10 man-made cave suites that blend seamlessly into the natural sandstone formations from which they are built. Each has a terrace and is equipped with a double bed and en-suite bathroom.

In addition to the caves, there are five thatched huts, modelled after the dwellings of San clans, who inhabited the area centuries ago. Each has a large bed and en-suite bathroom. Both accommodation types include air conditioning, and coffee-and-tea making facilities.

Onsite and nearby attractions

  • Restaurant, bar, swimming pool and spa on the reserve
  • Conference room, airfield, gift shop, and wi-fi in the main lodge only
  • Hiking, mountain-biking and Jeep trails in the surrounding nature reserve
  • Nature drives
  • Sundowner tours
  • Quad-bike adventures
  • Stargazing
  • Reptile educational talks presented by qualified snake handlers
  • Tours of ancient rock art sites, with paintings dating back 6 000 years

title.rendered: Le Petit Manoir: A Modern French Guesthouse in Franschhoek

content.rendered:
As a tourism hotspot, Franschhoek is bursting at the seams with places to stay, which means that competition is stiff and standards are perennially high. Yet still, newcomer Le Petit Manoir raises the bar when it comes to boutique hotels. While there is no shortage of hotels and guesthouses, there is a fine line between good and word-class. Having only opened in July 2018, Le Petit Manoir is proving that compact is king, with its beautifully appointed suites, world-class dining and buzzy location.

Proximity is everything

Situated on Franschhoek’s main drag (Huguenot Road for GPS purposes), the pint-sized guesthouse is perfectly positioned within walking distance of many of the town’s central attractions – a huge boon if you’re travelling without a vehicle.

This pocket of the world is endlessly proud of its French heritage, which shines through in the small cafés and boutiques, and charming village atmosphere – all on Le Petit Manoir’s doorstep.

Petite perfection

With just four suites, the intimate guesthouse feels more like a home, but with the service level of a five-star hotel. Each suite has a private balcony looking out onto the Franschhoek Mountains and the street below. Guests have access to the pool – which is flanked by the charming kitchen garden – and breakfast is part of the deal.

Four King Suites

  • Extra-length king-size bed
  • Private balcony
  • Nespresso machine
  • Complimentary tea and coffee pods
  • Telephone
  • Complimentary wi-fi
  • Complimentary drinks and snacks
  • Air conditioning

Cost From R3 570 per room (includes drink on arrival, daily breakfast, wi-fi, a bottle of wine and Molton Brown bathroom amenities)

Modern French

Like with many of the hotels in this neck of the wood, there are allusions to the classic French-country style aplenty but these are balanced by contemporary design details, giving the space a fresher and more current feel. As such, deep-buttoned headboards, muted colours and monogrammed pillows are offset by sleek blonde-timber furnishings, industrial-style lamps, and a streamlined open-plan black-and-concrete bathroom. It’s an effortless balance between comfort and sophistication.

Personal touch

The three owners – Brian Groenewald, JP Lombard and Frank Heyneke – are passionate food and hospitality fundis, with a global perspective and matching standards. The combined visual, interpersonal and business acumen each partner brings to the table make them a well-rounded and hands-on team – Frank and Brian were pitching in at dinner during my stay, and all three are consummate hosts and sticklers for detail and presentation.

X-factor food

The fourth member of the team and mastermind behind the extensive food offering at the hotel is Bloemfontein-born-and-raised Kevin Grobler. His impressive culinary track record includes stints at Terroir, Cavalli and Delaire Graff – and most recently as head chef at Michelin-starred JAN in Nice. The result of his impressive experience and skill and the warm and personal approach of the hotel as a whole is a food experience that while elevated isn’t pretentious.

Breakfast choices are succinct but intriguing – miso croque madame and chocolate quinoa make up two of your five choices – and lunch is à la carte, with dishes that are big on flavour style influences.

In the details

Details always decide which destinations make a lasting impression. For me, two things matter: fresh milk for coffee and tea, and the toiletries. Le Petit Manoir delivered on both of those – with flying colours: a jug in the minibar, and Molton Brown in the bathroom! These touches illustrate that the owners understand that the experience is the sum of the small details.

Other highlights were the beautifully stocked and stylish Smeg minibar, wood-burning fireplace, and a gorgeous freestanding tub… a reason to return when baths are back on the cards.

title.rendered: Klein Nektar Farm Cottage: Tranquil Accommodation in Montagu

content.rendered:
Situated in the quaint Karoo town of Montagu, this three-hectare working olive and wine farm sits in the heart of a tranquil valley. Providing the best of both worlds, this serene destination is a mere stroll from the shops and charming cafés of the town centre, and is also surrounded by endless nature, tucked away inside the towering Langeberg Mountains.

The property offers two entirely unique (yet equally special) accommodation units; either an exclusive stay in the farm’s original Cape Dutch Klein Nektar Manor, or a secluded self-catering escape in Klein Nektar’s Farm Cottage on the far edge of this 3-hectare town farm.

Sought-after seclusion

The charming self-catering Klein Nektar Farm Cottage is the ultimate spot for unhindered, low-key relaxation. Situated at the tip of a quiet olive-tree-lined road, the cottage is completely off the grid, which means there’s no electricity or wi-fi, but solar lamps, a gas-water heater, fridge, freezer, stove and oven ensure a relaxed and comfortable stay.

Accommodating up to four guests in two queen bedrooms with a shared bathroom, the cottage also boasts a charming open-plan living area that includes a fully equipped kitchen, lounge with a fireplace, and a dining area all nestled under an authentic reed ceiling. The private outdoor garden is ideal for braais, while the wrap-around terrace is the perfect spot for chilled summer lounging, offering a number of seating areas and views of the surrounding olive groves and paddocks. Not to mention a tempting daybed, with its promise of a lazy afternoon nap or read.

Country saunters

While the farm offers relaxing strolls through olive groves and orchards, if you’re looking for a more strenuous workout, there are walking, hiking and mountain-biking trails aplenty in the surrounding countryside. Culture vultures will enjoy the close proximity to Montagu’s cultural centre, where wonderful art galleries, cafés, shops, museums and restaurants await. And wine aficionados will relish being so close to the famous Route 62. Bird-watchers and fans of fishing will have loads to keep them busy, too.

But, actually, if you’d prefer to curl up with a good book, and catch up on some reading, that’s perfectly in order because, no matter how you choose to relax, after a stay at Klein Nektar, you’ll leave feeling recharged.

title.rendered: Africamps Klein Karoo: Luxury Camping Accommodation in Oudtshoorn

content.rendered:
Nothing says “escape into nature” like the Karoo – a semidesert landscape bathed in spiritual solitude. The Klein Karoo is separated from the Great Karoo by the Swartberg Mountain Range, and lies in a region that is sufficiently watered to bear lush vegetation (though some portions of it resemble the semidesert terrain that characterises the Karoo). This Africamps location, positioned around a dam on a working ostrich farm, serves as a gateway to this fascinating world.

Good to know This is one of several sites hosted by AfriCamps, a glamping service provider that collaborates with family-run farms and reserves to create luxury camping retreats. Other AfriCamps locations include AfriCamps at Pat Busch Mountain Reserve in Robertson, AfriCamps at Kam’Bati in Swellendam, AfriCamps at Ingwe in Plettenberg Bay, AfriCamps at Stanford Hills in Stanford, and last year’s editions: AfriCamps at Mackers, Hazyview and Africamps at Oakhurst in Wilderness.

Facilities

  • 12 luxury boutique camping tents, positioned around a big dam
  • Each tent has two queen-sized beds and a single bunk bed
  • Each tent has a fully equipped kitchen and en-suite bathroom
  • Each tent has a braai area and a wood-burning fireplace
  • Amenities include air conditioning, electric blankets and wi-fi
  • Breakfast and dinner baskets can be delivered to your tent at an additional charge
  • Daily lunch options available at the lapa

Activities

  • A tour of the working ostrich farm
  • Karoo safari
  • Stargazing
  • Meerkat encounter
  • Hiking trails

Nearby attractions

  • Cango Caves
  • Numerous restaurants, including Buffelsdrift Game Lodge restaurant, Nostalgie Restaurant and Karoo Pot

Pet policy Pets are not allowed on the farm, due to the presence of free roaming game.

title.rendered: Grande Provence: Tranquil Winelands Accommodation in Franschhoek

content.rendered:
One of the most historic (and breathtakingly beautiful) wine estates in the Franschhoek valley, Grande Provence is reminiscent of a French countryside escape, with a slice of homespun luxurious comfort thrown in.

Known for its sweeping vineyards, accolade-accruing restaurant and wonderful wine-tasting facilities, the estate is a veritable hole in one: a stylish spot to rest your head after a day spent exploring the village (a mere five minutes away), sipping top-drawer wines, or wandering around the estate.

The Owner’s Cottage

With five individually decorated rooms, The Owner’s Cottage is a stylish and intimate space that accommodates 10 people. Available to rent as an exclusive use guesthouse, or on a per-room-basis, it’s the ultimate home-away-from-home – complete with a pool, spacious lounge, dining room, garden and daily housekeeping.

There are four luxurious en-suite bedrooms, and one deluxe suite, each equipped with a minibar and coffee facilities, as well as a TV, DVD player and wi-fi. And, should you need it, there is also access to a guest computer, although we recommend that you stay unconnected to the outside world, and immerse yourself in the majesty of the surrounds.

Suite spot

This season, the estate is offering guests a wonderful Winter Heartland offer…

Angels Suite
Also called The Honeymoon Suite, Angels is on the ground floor and comes complete with a semi-private garden, indoor fireplace, king-sized bed, a luxurious en-suite bathroom, and a comfortable private lounge area.

Cabernet Room
An industrial-chic ground floor room that is luxurious and spacious, and opens onto a private garden patio and beautiful rose bushes. It has an en-suite bathroom and a king-sized bed (or two twins).

Shiraz Room
Also on the ground floor with a private garden patio, this spacious room features an en-suite bathroom and a king-sized bed (or two twins)

Merlot Room
This chic, thatched-roofed loft suite is dressed in warm, earthy tones. It comes with a king-sized bed (or two twins), an en-suite bathroom, and a private balcony overlooking the swimming pool and vineyards beyond.

Chardonnay Room
Also a chic thatched-roofed loft suite, this en-suite room features a king-sized bed (or two twins), and has a balcony overlooking the beautiful garden.

 

A winelands experience

Included in the room rate is a wonderful farm-style breakfast and a delectable three-course dinner at the estate’s esteemed restaurant. Guests also have full access to complimentary wine-tasting, and a tour of the on-site gallery and sculpture garden, both of which showcase some of South Africa’s finest established and emerging artists.

Those in need of some pampering might like to book an in-room massage… Or, if you feel like a dose of culture, coffee or a bout of shopping, venture into the village, a five-minute drive away.

With such wonderful accommodation, an abundance of activities and a magnificent country setting, the wine estate really is a grand(e) escape.

Good to know Families travelling with children may only rent the cottage on an exclusive-use basis, as bed & breakfast bookings for families with children under 12 years are not permitted.

Contact 021 876 8600, reservations@grandeprovence.co.za
Where to find it Main Road, Franschhoek

title.rendered: Le Quartier Français: A Chic Escape in Franschhoek

content.rendered:
Franschhoek’s hotel scene has never been slicker or chic-er than it is right now – thanks to a slew of spangly new openings and sparkly refurbs that have rolled into the village of late. One such revamp is Le Quartier Français – an eminent landmark on Franschhoek’s buzzy main road – that’s been given a refined yet contemporary overhaul, while still retaining the warmth and charm it’s always been known for.

Singh, Singh, Singh, Singh…

It’s near impossible to talk or write about Franschhoek without mentioning Analjit Singh, the Dehli-born billionaire-businessman and hotelier who paid a chance visit to Franschhoek during the Soccer World Cup in 2010, and subsequently bought two vineyards, two boutique hotels, shares in an art gallery, opening one Indian restaurant and a Taqueria and microbrewery in the process! Le Quartier Français, which was previously owned and beautifully run for more than two decades by hospitality heavyweight Susan Huxter, was one of Mr Singh’s acquisitions and, after a savvy and stylish makeover, relaunched in June 2018.

Lie of the land

Despite a comprehensive facelift, the new incarnation of Le Quaf (as it’s affectionately known) has retained many of the features that made its predecessor such a well-heeled and well-trodden destination. As such, service remains exemplary, the breakfast is still the most stylish in town, and the rooms are still imbued with colourful personality (but, in contrast to Ms Huxter’s brightly coloured aesthetic, the palette is somewhat quieter).

The layout remains the same: 32 rooms preside over an oval swimming pool that’s surrounded by a rose and jasmine garden, with a collection of adorably quirky baboon sculptures by artist Wilma Cruz (Mr Singh is known for his appreciation of art).

And, in addition to Protégé, the casual fine dining restaurant, the hotel is also home to the famed La Petite Colombe restaurant.

The rooms

There are 32 in total: nine Auberge Rooms, three Grande Rooms, three Petite Garden Suites, two Auberge Suites (with private pools), four state-of-the-art Four Quarters suites, and a three-bedroom Villa, all decorated by UK-based interior designer Beverly Boswell. The colour palette is fresh and vibrant, with French-style undertones (evident in the simple-patterned wallpapers and sumptuous upholstery fabrics) and African accents adding personality.

We stayed in a Four Quarter Suite – where we’d honeymooned nine years ago to the day – with our three-year-old son, who was beautifully looked after – with age-appropriate toys, books and fun toiletries laid out for us on arrival. And, while the reception we received on this family-friendly visit was decidedly different to our wedding night, it was done with the same thoughtful open-handedness.

Above and beyond

A hangover from its predecessor, the service is warm, personal and professional – in fact many of the original staff stayed on when Mr Singh took over, some of whom have worked there for over a decade! And it shows: they know how things work on the estate, and also the best places to recommend in the village and valley.

The wonderful boutique-style breakfast – one of the highlights of our honeymoon – did not disappoint this time around. The fruit, yoghurt and cereal course is served in chic jars and beautifully merchandised in colour-coded rows. The petite patisserie display includes gluten-free options, and the concise hot-breakfast menu has a mix of wholesome and decadent choices, such as homemade sweet waffles, with crispy streaky bacon and maple syrup; and a three-egg omelette, with garden spinach, boerenkaas and roasted tomatoes.

The hotel’s prime position on Franschhoek’s main road, within walking distance of excellent restaurants, galleries and boutiques, is another draw card. Le Quaf is a sumptuous, central and sophisticated stopover that won’t disappoint. To adapt a quote by esteemed American novelist Ernest Hemingway: ”When in Franschhoek, the only reason not to stay at Le Quartier Français is if you can’t afford it.” *

Contact 021 492 2222, reservations@leeucollection.com
Location Corner of Berg and Wilhelmina Streets, Franschhoek

* The original quote was about The Ritz in Paris in the 1940s, but we’ve never let a continent (or a few decades) stand in the way of a good story.

title.rendered: The Kite House: A Self-Catering Home in McGregor

content.rendered:
Situated in the charming town of McGregor, The Kite House is a private slice of country life, hidden in the upper village, away from the tourist-trodden guesthouses dotted in the centre of town.

Yours, and yours alone, this self-catering home offers magnificent views of the rolling hills, as well as picturesque gardens and a sparkling swimming pool, which comes in rather handy during the scorching summer when temperatures in the village soar. The ideal sanctuary for a peaceful city escape…

The rooms

With a main house that sleeps four, and an en-suite outside room that accommodates two (with basic amenities including a kettle, small bar fridge and toaster), The Kite House has capacity for the whole family (including the furry members!). All rooms are light and minimally decorated – with a unique kite hanging on the wall of each one, giving the various rooms their own personality.

Lie of the land

The kitchen is cleverly divided into two sections by a wall, with a hidden scullery, and an open-plan workspace flowing into the lounge and outdoor patio. Meal preparation is a festive affair, with a counter and barstools inviting friends to perch close by. Then, when eating’s done, and dishes have been cleared away (there’s no dishwasher, incidentally), spend the afternoon lounging under the eaves on the stoep, taking in unobstructed mountain and garden views.

Fido and friends

You’re in farm country here, so it’s not surprising that this is an animal-friendly abode. Bring the pooches, or any other pet-sized family members, and let them run around to their heart’s content. There’s also complimentary wi-fi, a fully installed DStv decoder with a small DSTV package, and a fireplace for hot chocolate-and-red-wine-fuelled winter nights, board games at the ready…

Nearby attractions

If you’re there over the weekend, head to the Saturday-morning market for fresh, homemade produce and delicious warm breakfast goodies – at wonderful country prices! Art lovers should take a stroll to the galleries along the town’s art route, and wine enthusiasts can visit an extensive selection of wineries in and around the town for superb wine-tasting and views to match.

There are also a number of hiking, and more leisurely walking trails, as well as cycle routes, with maps for all of these at the tourist office. Or, choose to simply relax and unwind with a massage at one of the local wellness spots, or with a book in the peaceful Temenos gardens.

Should you tire of home cooking, the town is teeming with a variety of places to grab a bite to eat and drink. We recommend Tebaldi’s at Temenos, Green Gables Country Inn Dining Room, Lady Grey Restaurant at Lord’s Guest Lodge, Eseltjiesrus Donkey Sanctuary Restaurant, 51 Voortrekker and Pizza Pazza.

Good to know Part of a larger, quieter development that values their peace and tranquillity, no large gatherings or parties are allowed.
Where to find it Van Reenen Street, McGregor

title.rendered: Schoone Oordt Country House: Laidback Luxury in the Heart of Swellendam

content.rendered:
As if it was plucked straight from the pages of Gone With The Wind, this Victorian mansion has been lovingly converted into a boutique hotel by charming hosts Alison and Richard Walker, who bought the property in 2003 and have been renovating it ever since. Who knows how many families have occupied this estate, how many stories it has to tell? The archives were destroyed by fire, so the owners have had to piece its past together using word-of-mouth stories. Still, guests continue to fall in love with the place, joining a long line of former occupants who hold a strong emotional connection to Schoone Oordt.

The rooms

There are eight Luxury Rooms, with private patios overlooking a vibrant rose garden. Each has a king-size or twin bed, en-suite bathroom with oversized showers, a fireplace, air conditioning, underfloor heating, uncapped wireless internet, a minibar, tea and coffee facilities, DStv and a DVD player.

There’s also a Family Cottage – a restored Coach House with its own private spot on the property – that sleeps four, with a king-size bed for parents, and a Family Suite that sleeps six. In addition to the above facilities, the cottage also has a small kitchenette with a microwave and toaster.

There’s also the Honeymoon Suite – where we stayed with our three-year-old son – set beside the Koornlands River on the edge of a forest, with a carved-wood four-poster bed, a capacious bathroom and a large fireplace enhancing the atmosphere.

Lie of the land

The grand old Manor House is the centrepiece of the estate, set apart from the guest rooms and surrounded by flourishing gardens with fountains and a saltwater swimming pool. Within the revamped mansion, there’s a bar and lounge with a fireplace, a country-style kitchen, and the Conservatory restaurant, which serves hearty breakfasts, afternoon tea, and dinners that evolve seasonally and are paired with locally sourced vintage wines.

Above and beyond

We arrived on one of those sweltering Swellendam days, and were welcomed by the warm and friendly staff into the tastefully appointed living room, where homemade lemonade, ice tea, freshly baked scones, and refreshing fruit bowls were laid out.

The three-course breakfast is an utter treat: start with the generous buffet that overflows with fresh fruit salad, an array of cereals and yoghurts, a charcuterie and cheese section, and freshly baked scones and jam! Ease into the second course – an utterly delicious watermelon, feta, rocket and toasted flaked almonds salad, and go all out with the main event – a Croque Madame with an English muffin-and-bacon twist!

On the day we left, our mud-splattered car received a full valet car wash.

And did we mention the warm, friendly and professional staff?

Nearby attractions

The staff at reception will happily advise you on how to spend your time in Swellendam, and the surrounding countryside. The best coffee is to be had at Ikigai Coffee Bar & Deli (across the road from Tourist Information, where you can hire mountain bikes). Other attractions include the history-rich Golden Mile, the Old Gaol (jailhouse), The Chocolate Shop and the Bee & Honey Shop. A short drive away is the Wildebraam Berry Estate (guests can join in during the berry-picking season), the Sulina Faerie & Healing Sanctuary, and a nine-hole golf course.

Outdoor activities for adventure-seekers include river rafting on the Breede River, mountain biking, horse-riding and hiking trails. Children will enjoy a trip to The Swellendam Getaway Adventure Farm, where they can explore the maze, go on a tractor ride or enjoy some paintballing.

title.rendered: Silver Bay Villa: The Ultimate Seaside Escape on The West Coast

content.rendered:
The West Coast is an unparalleled getaway destination, known for its wild seas, untouched wilderness, and endless natural beauty. In a stream of quaint seaside towns lining its majestic shores, endless beach houses beckon to become unforgettable weekend escapes. One such place is Silver Bay Villa.

Less than two hours from the hustle and bustle of Cape Town, this luxe self-catering villa offers uninterrupted ocean views, direct access to the beach, and an interior worthy of double-page spreads in the finest decor mags. It’s got the white walls, thatched roof and warm comfort of a lovable beach house, but with a special sprinkling of extra-special luxury.

Just looking at the photographs, we can already imagine the taste of a crisp mimosa on the deck at sunset.

Belle of the beach

Located at the very tip of the coastline, with a sprinkling of properties, the area is already a contender for the best weekend getaways. Staying in a ultra-cool villa with everything that opens and closes is just the cherry on top.

Resting on a sand dune with uninterrupted views of St Helena and Stompneus Bays, the villa gives you a feeling of peaceful seclusion you wouldn’t otherwise find if staying in the town centre. The large glass windows allow you to enjoy the sunrise, sunset, and everything in between, without having to move a muscle… But with the beach below – accessed by a private boardwalk – you’ll definitely want to.

Silver linings galore

Sleeping up to eight people, every element of this beautifully-appointed two-storey home has been carefully considered to ensure the ultimate stay.

Villa features

  • Four en-suite bedrooms with queen-size beds
  • Fully-equipped kitchen
  • Two open-plan living areas with DStv and wifi
  • Two fireplaces and underfloor heating
  • Protected outdoor courtyard
  • Rim-flow pool
  • Laundry room
  • Kids’ playroom
  • Secure garage
  • 24-hour security

Kitted out for winter and summer, this luxury beach house is the ultimate destination for a seaside holiday away from it all with family or friends.

title.rendered: The Homestead at Oldenburg Vineyards is a Winelands Fantasy Come True

content.rendered:
The winding stretch of road between Stellenbosch and Franschhoek is arguably one of the most beautiful mountain passes in the world, snaking its way past a handful of vista-drenched, internationally renowned wine estates.

Oldenburg Vineyards is one such destination. Nestled in a corner of the Banhoek Valley, somewhere between the Drakenstein and Simonsberg mountains, this 40-hectare farm is home to a charming, immaculately renovated 200-year-old Cape Dutch homestead, whose rich and chequered history has deep significance for its current owner Adrian Vanderspuy, who was born on the neighbouring farm.

His grandmother lived in the historic homestead for over 50 years and, even though Adrian was raised abroad, he and his family would return each year to visit his grandmother on the farm where she eventually died. The property passed into a trust in 1993, but went up for sale in 2003, which is when Adrian snapped it up, and began the process of restoring and renovating the house that holds so many fond childhood memories…

Views for days

We arrived at the farm at sunset, as the mountains were turning a gazillion shades of orange, and the sun’s last rays were trickling through the bright-green leaves of the ancient oak trees lining the driveway. Before entering the homestead and checking out our lodgings for the next two nights, we lingered outside, marvelling at the utter majesty of the setting: miles and miles of vineyards as far as the eye can see, and majestic wrap-around mountain views stretching into infinity…

Creature comforts

Inside, the villa’s lofty proportions, chic decor and state-of-the art appliances will impress even the most well-heeled globetrotters. And, while the house has been given an utterly modern overhaul, complete with all the trappings of a ultra-high-end villa, the homestead retains the charm and character of its Cape Dutch roots. At Oldenburg, the emphasis is on homeliness and warmth – the kind that can perhaps only be found in a place with such a rich personal history.

The younger members of our party made a weekend pastime of unearthing all the surreptitiously concealed high-tech features, high-fiving each other every time they discovered a new gadget – from the electronic shutters that allow you to black-out your room at the push of a button to the underfloor heating in the light and airy, double-volume kitchen, to the hidden speakers in all the living areas, and even the nifty magnetised water dispenser and glasses in the bedrooms (that stick to the tray when you put them down to prevent spillage).

Great panes

As you’d expect from a farmhouse worth its (Maldon Sea) salt, the heart of this homestead is a dreamy, double-volume eat-in kitchen that’s fully equipped with everything that opens and closes.

But, perhaps, the most abiding feature of this homely-yet-hitech kitchen is the massive counter-to-ceiling sash window that maximises the breathtaking mountain and vineyard views on all sides. Some of our most memorable moments of the weekend were spent sitting at the long dining table, enjoying lazy breakfasts (and cosy dinners), marvelling at the outside vistas.

Effortless entertaining

In addition to the kitchen, there’s a more formal dining room, adjacent to the impressive glass-walled wine cellar, that’s home to a 12-seater walnut table, and a series of antiques and collectibles (some of which belonged to Adrian’s grandmother), but we chose to dine in the kitchen for the duration of our stay.

Even the outdoor braai beneath an enormous oak tree on the swimming-pool veranda couldn’t lure us away from the comfort of the cosy kitchen… (In our defence, our stay was during winter, which is still not an excuse for not making an outdoor braai against the breathtaking backdrop of mountains and vineyards!)

Sleep easy

The villa comfortably sleeps 12 guests in six warm and luxurious bedrooms, each with their own bathroom (five are en-suite), and equipped with all the bells and whistles you’d expect: air-conditioning, underfloor heating (in the bathrooms, too), wi-fi, flat-screen TVs (with DStv, Netflix and Apple TV available), heated towel rails, and so on. And, just like the rest of the home, the decor in the bedrooms is stylish and the palette is pared-down.

The eaten track

Gourmands will feel like they’ve died and gone to food-and-wine heaven being at Oldenburg, whose Helshoogte neighbours include the award-winning restaurants at Delaire Graff and Tokara. Other top-drawer wining-and-dining options in this neck of the woods are Babel at Babylonstoren and Terroir at Kleine Zalze.

Or, if you’d prefer to source your own gourmet ingredients, there are numerous delis and farmers’ markets in the nearby towns of Franschhoek and Stellenbosch.

Oldenburg’s tasting room, a stone’s throw from the homestead, is the perfect way to while away an afternoon, sampling some of the farm’s award-winning nectars.

On nature’s doorstep

One of the highlights of our stay was the three-hour hike we enjoyed on our first morning there. The homestead’s unique (and enviable) location in the depths of a valley, with impossibly easy access to endless nature, was an unexpected bonus for nature-lovers like ourselves. After a leisurely breakfast, we literally slammed the frontdoor behind us, and within seconds we were on a dirtroad, making our way up the mountain, passing neighbouring farms, waterfalls, pebbled riverbeds, a dam, and the odd mountain-biker along the way.

And, even though we were on private property, there are no fences and gates, so you can wander for miles and miles. The privacy and seclusion is invigorating, and we felt incredibly safe – and at peace – with towering mountains all around us.

Outside interests

Back at the homestead, some of our party spent the rest of the afternoon reclining on the verandah sofas – vino in hand – while the children played endless games of catch, soccer and cricket on the velvety front lawn, and the foodies among us rustled up a late lunch. The sleek, glass-fronted view-drenched gym beckoned, but none of us felt the urge.

At the end of our weekend, ensconced in a luxury villa and surrounded by the majesty and serenity of nature, we left Oldenburg Vineyards feeling relaxed, rejuvenated and ready to take on the world.

title.rendered: To the Manor House Born

content.rendered:
There’s no shortage of five-star hotels at the V&A Waterfront – which is hardly surprising, given its stunning view-drenched location, and its close and convenient proximity to many of the city’s world-famous (and also lesser-known) tourist attractions.

So, when we heard that a brand-new luxury property was opening its doors in May 2017, we were curious to find out how – if at all – it differed from its local counterparts.

Fit for a queen

Like all the other properties at the V&A, the Queen Victoria Manor House has loads going for it – not least of all its unfettered vistas of Table Mountain, the marina and the city’s flourishing skyline, which is particularly lovely at night when the cityscape is a sea of twinkly lights.

But what makes this property stand apart is its size (there are just four suites), location (moments away from the tourist-trodden mall, but tucked away in a secluded corner), and its unique service offering (private butler, anyone?).

Part of the Newmark Hotel Group (whose Waterfront portfolio includes the neighbouring Queen Victoria Hotel, Dock House Boutique Hotel and Victoria & Alfred Hotel as well as Dash and Ginja restaurants), this four-roomed super-luxe property was exquisitely decorated by Francois du Plessis who has created plush yet pared-down suites that ooze glamour and comfort.

Lie of the land

The hotel’s discreet location, away from the shopping precinct, but close enough to walk to, makes it perfect for travellers who like to dip in and out of the action. The fact that the Queen Victoria hotel’s in-house restaurant is a minute stroll away means that you don’t have to venture far to take your meals. Plus guests have access to all its sister properties’ facilities: a fully functional gym (available 24 hours), the Sanctuary Signature Spa right next door, as well as full conference facilities at The Forum.

If you’d prefer to take your meals alone, there’s a private dining room that accommodates up to six guests in the annexure. Guests can specify their prefered menus, which will be prepared by the kitchen staff at Dash.

Ask Jeeves

We were welcomed to our suite by our bright-faced butler, Gershwin, who’d lined up treats for the whole family: an Adventure Colouring Pack Pack for our toddler, and a chilled bottle of Graham Beck Brut for us! He offered to unpack for us, which we declined, but told us he was at our beck and call until 11pm that night, and from 6am the next day.

Keen to test drive his services, we put in a detailed coffee order for the following morning – (even though, for the record, I’d have been quite content with the output from the Nespresso machine in our suite ).
After drinks and dinner at Dash, we collapsed in our massive king-size bed for a delicious night’s sleep, only to be awoken by our toddler slightly earlier than anticipated.

Gagging for our caffeine hit, we rang Gershwin to ask for an earlier delivery. Lo and behold, our coffee arrived minutes later, but not as specified… I drank mine, which was delicious, but my partner stuck to his guns and waited for what he’d ordered – which he knocked back as promptly as it was delivered.

Above and beyond

The Pink Pepperpod Body Wash by Molton Brown, whose heavenly scent infused our capacious bathroom after I bathed in it (note to the Water Gestapo: it was a shallow bath, that I shared with my toddler). All the Molton Brown products – from the body lotion, hand cream, shampoo and conditioner – smack of quality and sensual delights; you feel as if you’ve had a mini spa experience in your bathroom. The best part? Gershwin informed us that the sample sizes were ours to take home.

Royal flush

Another wow moment was pulling up the blind in the loo, which revealed a close-up of the CapeWheel – pretty dazzling at night. Oh, and the premium, luxury-weight towels that are super-absorbent and utterly comforting.

Rates From R5 095 per room per night (includes full breakfast and butler)
Where to find it Portswood Road, Waterfront

title.rendered: Tranquil luxury at Paarl’s Cascade Country Manor

content.rendered:
Located around 50 minutes out of Cape Town, Cascade Country Manor Guesthouse & Spa is strongly reminiscent of a Beverly Hills mansion – minus the pretentiousness.

A pearl in Paarl


Situated in the heart of the central Cape Winelands, a mere 10 to 15 minutes away from Paarl, this royal-homestead-turned family-run guesthouse and luxury spa makes for the ideal country escape, romantic getaway or wonderful Western Cape introduction.

Lap of luxury

Leave the nearby rural farmlands and gravel road behind, and allow yourself to be transported to this secluded haven of grandeur and tranquility, set in the midst of ancient olive groves, with the Klein Drakenstein Mountains as a picturesque backdrop.

Outside, the vibrant gardens and eternally tempting pool area are deliciously crisp and well-maintained, despite our drought-stricken times (thanks no doubt to Cascade Country Manor’s mindful water-saving policies).

As you approach the stately main building or enter the delightful courtyard – complete with quintessential gurgling fountain – the initial sense of Hollywood glamour fades, becoming something far nobler. Soak up the manor’s old-world, Mediterranean charm (with a touch of White House pillar flare…) before you enter Cascade’s tantalisingly cool depths and become oblivious to even Paarl’s summer heat.

What lies within


The guesthouse is luxuriously equipped with all the desired amenities of a modern hotel. Its 15 luxurious and individually designed rooms offer chic modernity and old-world touches – including refurbished antique furniture, like the solid African rosewood and delicate chandeliers.

Our double classic room offered a glorious terrace, with lovely mountain views and all manner of necessary amenities (included in all rooms): a TV, well-stocked minibar, complimentary tea and coffee tray, telephone, hairdryer, air-conditioning and an en-suite bathroom, with a wonderful, spacious walk-in shower.

Fun inside and out

Whether you’re after enjoying mountain biking, swimming, walking trails, abseiling or even some olive and olive-oil tasting at this idyllic retreat, Cascade Country Manor has you sorted.

It’s also a stunning event and function venue, for the likes of weddings and conferences, and occasionally hosts its own concerts. During our weekend stay, we were fortunate to be treated to the impressive sounds of Sterling EQ, as the Full Moon Valentine’s Concert got underway.

Unlocking Paradise

Cascade Spa – which we were generously invited to enjoy, if time allowed – is the newest addition to this boutique hotel. The intimate wellness centre offers specialist and all-purpose spa treatments. Guests can also enjoy wellness talks, adventure walks and olive oil tastings or advised purchasings of pampering, chemical-free skincare products.

Buffet to remember


After a peaceful night’s undisturbed sleep, wander down to the verandah (which offers amazing views across the garden) for a breakfast buffet, with a choice of fresh fruits, cheese and bread options, muesli and more. You can also order a hot breakfast from the hotel’s wonderful restaurant, which owner Volker Goetze has ensured provides guests with some signature South African dishes. I chose the Eggs Benedict, with smoked salmon and hollandaise sauce and it was truly delicious!

Cascading beauty


If you have time, the manor’s namesake – the cascading waterfall – is a must-see. Lying some 200 metres away, at the end of the olive-lined avenue, it is indeed a sight for sore eyes.

Because our visit came so soon after the terrible, all-consuming wildfires, which ravished parts of Paarl during January, it was especially heartening to see that many of their bridges, trees and shrubbery had survived the inferno.

Stellar service throughout

From the moment we arrived until our heavy-hearted departure, Cascade Country Manor and its great, efficient and, above all, welcoming staff, made us feel like royalty! We received the highest level of service and wonderful care from everyone involved, most notably generous host Maike Goetze, general manager Barry Geyer and Isabel from the front desk.

Our only complaint was that we had to leave its tender, luxurious embrace…

Room rate
R1 320 (classic single room) – R 2860 (deluxe room for two) (depending on type of room and number of people sharing)
R300 for children, ages 5 – 12 (limited to certain rooms)
Where to find it Cascade Country Manor, Waterval Road, Nederburg, Paarl

Thank you to Paarl Tourism for their kind assistance and high recommendation of Cascade Country Manor – and, of course, to Cascade Country Manor for hosting us so soon after the devastating Paarl fires.

title.rendered: Radisson RED at The Silo District: There’s No Other Hotel Like It

content.rendered:
An exciting mix of sexy-looking design and cool-kid innovation, the new Radisson RED Hotel in the V&A Waterfront’s trendy Silo district is a tech-savvy millennial’s delight. Free high-speed wifi in every nook and cranny? Tick! An app that lets you do everything – from check-out to networking with other guests? Yep! “Love yourself lighting” to snap the perfect selfie? You got it!

The hotel’s 252 studios serve up killer city views, but the best spot to really soak up your surroundings is the Red Roof, a rooftop pool, bar and grill where you can knock back a sundown shake or craft beer from a bright-red street food-inspired truck-bar, called Van Rouge.

If you’re really ravenous, head down to the OUIBar + KTCHN, a social hub that serves everything from gourmet burgers and fiery tacos made from local seasonal produce to Hill’s Science pet food. Oh, you didn’t you know? The hotel even extends it’s hospitality to your fur baby! If not, the resident Boston Terrier, Baxter – who’s also the hotel’s brand ambassador – might get lonely.

What’s happening at Radisson RED in December 2017?

While there’s always something hot happening at Radisson RED, there are two upcoming events you don’t want to miss.

First up is the Festive Feast on Christmas Day, where guests will be treated to a picnic-style gourmet lunch that includes everything from red wine and pear-infused turkey to mince pies and toasty waffles served with a myriad of indulgent toppings that’ll make you glad the hotel has a state-of-the-art gym. (R695 per person; kids under 12 eat for free and also receive a little surprise from Santa.)

The other not-to-be-missed event is a rocking New Year’s Eve Rooftop Bash (R1 800 per person) with DJs Dino and Roger Goode. Guests can expect a decadent butcher’s braai, more street food than you can shake a stick at, a rather fancy G&T on arrival, and bubbles as well as fireworks when the clock strikes 12.

Contact 087 086 1578, baxter@radissonred.co.za
Room rates From around R2 500 – R4 800 (depends on occupancy and time of the year)

title.rendered: Old-World Luxury at Akademie Street Boutique Hotel & Guest House in Franschhoek

content.rendered:
The words “a home away from home” greet you at the peaceful entrance and, after a peek inside the wonderful walls of this award-winning boutique hotel, you’ll quickly understand the sentiment.

Built in the 19th century – and one of the longest-standing properties in Franschhoek (and certainly the most central) – Akademie Street Boutique Hotel & Guest House holds a certain old-world charm that is particularly sought-after when seeking a stay in a small resort town.

But of course you don’t accrue awards and accolades without the luxe factor, which is exactly what this peaceful paradise offers its guests, along with personalised hospitality and a sense of seclusion.

Home comforts

A short walk from the bustling culinary hotspots and shops on the main road, the establishment boasts eight individually styled suites, three spacious cottages, four pools and three wood-burning hot tubs.

There’s also a chic indoor lounge where the resident pianist sets the scene with soft tunes, the conservatory-style Orangerie where guests can lounge and enjoy everything from breakfast to cocktails, a library, tranquil courtyard gardens, an outdoor pergola for intimate dining experiences (on request), and a comfortable indoor bar for late-night chats or early morning cuppas spread across the breathtaking property.

Reasons to believe

All beverages and snacks (including in each suite), as well as breakfast, are included in the room rate, and guests are encouraged to enjoy this generosity to the full. Every room has its own personality, yet the sense of comfort is consistent throughout, with unique facilities taking things up a notch – we love the bluetooth gramophones!

Guests are granted their very own smartphone upon arrival, which has been loaded with the numbers of local restaurants and activities for their perusal. There are also 19th century-style bikes available should the mood for exploration strike.Akademie is the perfect mix of down-to-earth hospitality and luxe living – everything has been carefully considered, yet nothing feels pretentious or contrived – making it a one-of-a-kind retreat.

A curated collection

Twyfelings

Twyfeling A, B, and C are the three suites located inside the hotel’s Manor House, each of which has its own unique charm, and all are located a mere stumble from the main bar, library and lounge areas. Guests staying here also have direct access to the main garden, pool and Jacuzzi.

Room features:

  • An extra-length king size bed
  • Freestanding vintage bath and shower
  • Underfloor heating
  • Wood-burning fireplace
  • A private walled courtyard

Twyfeling A

Twyfeling B

Twyfeling C

Cost From R6 000 – R8 500 per room per night (depending on season)

Uitsig

Taking pride of place on the top floor of one of the main buildings, alongside the garden courtyard, the Uitsig suite is a wonderful choice for those seeking cosseted seclusion.

French doors open to the bright and breezy interior, where the extra-length king size bed hugged in luxury linen and opulent marble-coated bathroom await you for your stay. There’s also complete underfloor heating for when the evening chill kicks in.
The space In addition to a private staircase, the suite boats magical mountain views from its private terrace, which boasts a hidden wood-fired hot tub, and offers guests personal access to the main gardens, heated pool, and Jacuzzi.
Cost From R7 000 – R9 500 per room per night (depending on season)

Gelantheid

With its stylish, pared-down palette and original hardwood floors, this two-storey-high Cape Dutch-style cottage is the largest on the property. Guests have shared access to a downstairs patio, private pool, sun deck and Jacuzzi.
The space There are individual two suites (Gelantheid A and B) spread over the ground and upper floor, that are connected by a wooden staircase. Each has a lounge with a fireplace, a kitchen and dining area, spacious bedroom and bathroom with a freestanding bath, a private wood burning hot tub (made with Cape brandy barrels!), and two balconies.
Cost From R8 000 – R10 500 per room per night (depending on season)

Oortuiging

Built in 1865 and used as an army recruiting office during the Boer War, this Cape Dutch cottage is steeped in fascinating history. Decorated with antique furniture with a neural colour palette, the cottage lends itself to the era in which it was built – making a stay here feel like a passage back in time.
The space The cottage boasts two one-bedroom suites (Oortuiging A and B), an open-plan lounge area, kitchen and dining room, and is available for exclusive rentals or on a per-room basis. Each room has access to its own private hot tub, while guests have shared use of the personal outdoor courtyard and plunge pool.
Cost From R 9 000 – R11 500 per room per night (depending on season)

Vreugde

With its own picturesque private garden, wood-burning hot tub, outdoor shower and fully equipped living area, this signature cottage is the perfect pick for travellers who prize sumptuous seclusion.
The space The bedroom is home to an Italian-style canopy bed, and a double antique vanity counter, while the bathroom offers a free-standing (handmade) brass bath, and a seperate shower. There is underfloor heating for when the cold kicks in, while your very own personal plunge pool will be a dream come true during the toasty summer.
Cost From R10 000 – R12 500 per room per night (depending on season)

Good to know The property is not pet-friendly. No children under 16.
Cost From R6 000 – R12 500 (includes all beverages and breakfast)

title.rendered: The Ultimate Beach Escape: Birkenhead House

content.rendered:
Somebody once wrote: “A luxury hotel promises something all travellers dream of: a lavish break from daily life and a sumptuous journey into an opulent otherworld.” Which is exactly what Birkenhead House is – and more.

Impossible-to-beat location

Perched on a peninsula overlooking the entire coast of Walker Bay, this elegant hotel’s cliffside location gives some of the swankiest spots on the Amalfi Coast a run for their money. Just a three-minute drive from the bustling village of Hermanus, it’s perfectly positioned for those who cherish seclusion but also enjoy dipping in and out of the action.

Restrained elegance


The 11-room hotel was once the Biden family’s holiday home until they decided to turn it into posh lodgings, with Liz (Biden) in charge of decorating it. Her eclectic style vacillates between glam-opulence and beachside chic, with pillars and marble floors setting the scene throughout, and deep, white slip-covered couches in all the communal lounge areas. Curling up on one of these ocean-facing sofas, with a G&T to hand, while you watch the whales and dolphins frolic in the bay is sheer bliss.

Glorius isolation


Our plush sea-facing room is the last word in hushed opulence, with a gold-framed headboard on our king-size bed, leather desk, furry throws, a long sofa and a glam-luxe marble bathroom offsetting the muted palette. Ensconced in our private paradise, we feel totally isolated from the 10 other guest quarters… as if the entire beach belongs to us. But a site tour earlier with chummy Ricardo reveals that the ocean-facing rim-flow pool, sun deck and dining area are a short stroll away. (The hotel’s other pool is a split-level number that’s quite impressive.)

Above & beyond

Attentive service and cliffside location aside, perhaps the most unique aspect of this intimate lodge is that everything (except cigars, reserve wines and spa treatments) is included in the room rate. All meals, obviously, as well as the freshly baked cakes on the buffet table that tempt me every single time I pass by, to the fully (and I mean FULLY) equipped bar in our room, stocked with an assortment of the classiest tipples in the world. (Bombay Sapphire and Johnnie Walker Black Label, to name a few).

Dining with a view


The upscale yet laidback restaurant is headed by executive chef Oliver Coetzee, who rustles up small plates inspired by the hotel’s coastal setting in his busy kitchen. As you’d expect from this ultra-high-end establishment, menus and meals can be designed to meet your individual tastes and dietary requirements, and can be taken wherever you desire: on the cliffside terrace, by the pool, in the glass-fronted dining area, or in the privacy of your suite.

Room rate From R3 800 per person sharing (depending on season and type of room; includes all meals and drinks, excluding reserve wines)
Where to find it Birkenhead House, Corner 11th Street and 7th Avenue, Voelklip, Hermanus

title.rendered: The sizzle of South Beach – in Camps Bay

content.rendered:
Moments away from the ever-buzzing palm-fringed Camps Bay Promenade stands South Beach, an exclusive block of 19 holiday apartments that offers new-gen travellers luxury and style without foregoing any of the comfort and convenience that big-chain five-star hotels provide.

PERFECTLY POSITIONED

South Beach has loads going for it – beautiful interiors designed by architect Greg Wright, two sizeable swimming pools, a private gym, complimentary high speed wi-fi, and more – but the thing that made our stay special is its lovely location – one street back from Camps Bay’s boisterous Main Road, ensuring privacy and discretion – but close enough to dip into the activity should the moment arise.

SOPHISTICATED LUXURY


Each of the light and airy apartments is beautifully dressed in white; the only bursts of colour come courtesy of Lionel Smit, whose cool artworks adorn the walls. But there’s nothing sterile about our luxurious, pared-down digs. In fact, the clean lines and uncluttered open-plan space provide a blank canvas within which we can create our own perfect (and private) holiday, far away from themed buffets and umbrella cocktails.

WHEN IN CAPE TOWN…

The sense of independence (not to mention seclusion and space) that comes with staying in a self-catering apartment is part of what makes a holiday memorable. Shopping for groceries at one of the Cape’s finest farmers’ markets and filling your hire-car with petrol means you get to experience the Mother City as a local, not as a tourist.
South Beach also has a fleet of cool bicycles that are free and available to use should you feel like taking a scenic ride along the coast…
And if you’re planning to overdose on vitamin sea, you’ll be hard-pressed to find a spot that ticks all the boxes and is situated so close to one of Cape Town’s best beaches. There are also some stunning hikes in and around the Mother City waiting to be tackled.

CALL THE CONCIERGE

For some, the downside of self-catering means having to make your own bed (not the case here) and do your own laundry. At South Beach, the choice is yours. There’s a good-quality iron and ironing board in each room, as well as a communal self-service laundry. But if you’d prefer to outsource those daily chores, call the concierge and he’ll arrange it.

EAT, DRINK, PLAY

With a 47-inch TV, sound bar, wireless headsets in our rooms, not to mention a state-of-the-art kitchen (complete with Nespresso machine), it might be difficult to peel yourself away from your room. Should you wish to venture out, there’s a slew of chic restaurants and alfresco cafés on your doorstep where you can sample some of the Cape’s wonderful local flavours.

title.rendered: The ultimate Franschhoek getaway: Babylonstoren

content.rendered:
It’s the little things…

A beautifully curated collection of books in every room
Warming wood-burning fires
Silky sarongs
Gorgeous L’Occitane grooming treats
Sturdy wellies for walking your way around
A gentle knock on the door at 7pm, presenting a glass of perfectly chilled white wine and a jar of mint-marinated farm olives.
It’s the little things…


Mountain bikes to explore the farm (or to pedal over to Babel for dinner, with a moonlit detour through the garden, of course)
The child-friendly atmosphere that encourages happy laughs
The wholesome sense of coming home
And a spaciousness that ensures supreme privacy without feeling isolated.
It’s the little things…

A heavenly mix

This heavenly mixture of laidback farm-style delights and world-class creature comforts appears to be effortless but it must’ve entailed tremendous planning. It’s clear that owner Karen Roos combined the very best experiences from her travels abroad, and masterfully merged those with the very best local flavours. From Provençal-inspired gardens bearing fruit that made the Cape of Good Hope a vital pitstop, to luxurious suites that are replicas of the old farms worker’s cottages, to food fit for the gods. Karen’s innate sense of style (nonchalantly teaming a Kartell side table with a deep, old-fashioned bathtub) and her scrupulous attention to detail puts the city’s most lavish hotels to shame.

Whether it’s a romantic getaway, a family weekend, a special event or just the pure pleasure of experiencing the fresh air, legendary gourmet offerings and pampering atmosphere that is Babylonstoren, it’s the little things that will delight you.

And they add up to quite a lot, actually.

BLISSED OUT

Babel: It’s no surprise that it’s near impossible to get a booking at the surprisingly informal, yet still sleek and sophisticated main restaurant. Dinnertime entails being thoroughly entertained by the waiters’ knowledgeable presentation of what’s on offer – totally tantalising, and fitting foreplay for what’s to come. The simple menu, that changes seasonally to maximise what’s on offer in the farm’s garden, is just genius. For example, a pre-dinner drink comprising vodka, grapefruit juice and vanilla sets the tone for the simple, fresh and beautifully orchestrated flavours, such as sublime fillet on the bone done to perfection (not well done!) and salads with heady mixes of freshly picked fruit and vegetables. The indulgent breakfasts are no different: delicately prepared eggs, bacon and farm sausage, magical mueslis, Provence-sized hunks of cheese and delights such as gluten-free polenta-bread (and rice milk) on tap.

Garden tour at 10am: Sure, it’s utterly lovely to amble through this garden of biblical proportions on your own, but even those who are indifferent to plants will be floored by the sheer scale of the stream of stories offered by Liesl or Gundula.

Sip and savour: Every room comes with complimentary bottles of Babylonstoren wines (best enjoyed at sunset on your picture-perfect private verandah), but there’s more in store for your taste buds… Head over to the wine cellar and tasting area for a superb wine tour (complete with a side show on the farm’s formidable olive oil enterprise) and end it off with a languid hour or two in the elegant simplicity of the modern glass-fronted tasting room. Here, heavenly platters (farm-fresh bread, moist biltong, exotic fruits and moreish veggies, duckliver pâté, goat’s cheese truffles…) complete the picture. TIP: do not leave before trying their bubbly and inimitable Nebukadnesar flagship red blend.

Ah… spa: Whether or not your opt for a treatment in the lush and oh-so-zen spa, guests are still welcome to use the fabulous facilities (heated indoor pool with shoulder-massaging water jets, sauna, steam room and an outdoor plaasdam-style pool and a sandpit strip, for sun seekers).

Cost: From R6 600 (depending on season)
Location: Babylonstoren
